inlineContent.text: , you can change the configuration parameters.

The configuration allows the configuration and customization of several VigramSDK components. Make sure to change the configuration before using the VigramSDK in your app (e.g. in your AppDelegate or your class - helper SDK), since changing these values might or might not be respected dynamically.

code: import Combine
import VigramSDK
final class YouVigramHelper: NSObject {
public init() {
super.init()
// Previous step. Can be moved to a separate function.
func autenticationSDK()
// All configuration parameters are presented below.
// Current version of SDK.
// This variable returns the current version of the SDK.
let currentSDKVersion: String = Configuration.sdkVersion
// The default changing of rate.
// This parameter is used to change the refresh rate of
// viDoc data.
// Range: 1-10 Hz (7Hz by default)
Configuration.defaultRate = .hertz7 // set 7Hz
// Debug SDK Configuration
// When set to `true`, this flag causes more verbose log
// output.
// Note: Set false if not debug mode (false by default)
Configuration.debug = false
// The maximum packet size sent over Bluetooth Low Energy
// connections. Messages sent over bluetooth with a size
// larger than this value will be split up into smaller
// packets and sent sequentially without the interferences
// of concurrently sent messages. (200 bits by default)
// Note: In most cases, this value should not be changed.
Configuration.maximumBLEPacketSize = 200
// The packet size for device messages sent over Bluetooth
// Low Energy connections. Device messages sent over
// bluetooth with a size larger than this value will be
// split up into smaller packets and sent sequentially
// without the interferences of concurrently sent messages.
// (4 bits by default)
// Note: In most cases, this value should not be changed.
Configuration.deviceBLEPacketSize = 4
// The time interval to wait between sending BLE messages.
// Once a message is sent, the specified amount of time
// will be waited, before the next message is sent.
// (0.01 sec by default)
// Note: In most cases, this value should not be changed.
Configuration.bleSendInterval = 0.01
// The timeout interval to send a disconnect signal when a
// gpsService is unused but actively connected.
// NTRIP connections and active bluetooth connections can
// be quite expensive and/or battery-consuming.
// A GPSService will send out a disconnect signal after
// disconnectSignalTimeout seconds after the service was
// created or the last recording has been stopped.
// (3 min by default)
// Note: In most cases, this value should not be changed.
Configuration.disconnectSignalTimeout = 3 * 60.0
// The interval to wait between NMEA-0183 GGA message
// forwards to the NTRIP correction service. This
// interval will ensure that GGA messages are not sent
// in a higher frequency than 1 / ntripSendInterval.
// Setting this interval to 0, will forward all
// GGA messages to the NTRIP
// correction service. (1.0 sec by default)
// Note: In most cases, this value should not be changed.
Configuration.ntripSendInterval = 1.0
// The timeout interval to cancel an NTRIP connection
// attempt. NTRIP connections might take quite some time
// to be established, especially with an unreliable
// internet connection. (20.0 sec by default)
Configuration.ntripTimeout = 20.0
// Peripheral start timeout
// The timeout interval to wait during start after the
// connection has been established and before configuration
// starts. (0.5 sec by default)
Configuration.peripheralStartTimeout = 0.5
// Attention! The next set of configuration parameters
// is the most important, as these parameters affect the
// SinglePoints measurements.
// Changing values ​​may increase/decrease measurement
// accuracy.
// Too small values ​​with low accuracy will produce SP
// measurement errors. Too large values ​​will skip bad
// measurements.
// Note: A detailed description of SinglePoints
// measurements will be discussed in step 8.
// The maximum altitude difference to be tolerated between
// individual measurements during single point recordings.
// If the altitude of an individual measurement differs from
// the median measurement by more than this value, it is not
// included in the final calculation. (0.05 by default)
Configuration.maximumSinglePointAltitudeDifference = 0.05
// The maximum horizontal accuracy to be tolerated for
// individual measurements during single point recordings.
// If the horizontal accuracy of an individual measurement
// exceeds this value, it is not included in the final
// calculation. (0.05 by default)
Configuration.maximumSinglePointHorizontalAccuracy = 0.05
// The maximum vertical accuracy to be tolerated for
// individual measurements during single point recordings.
// If the vertical accuracy of an individual measurement
// exceeds this value, it is not included in the final
// calculation. (0.05 by default)
Configuration.maximumSinglePointVerticalAccuracy = 0.05
// The middle antenna height.
// Distance from the bottom of the antenna to the center (cm).
// (3.57 cm by default - If you are using a non-standard
// device antenna, change this value)
// Note: Detailed information on these parameters can be found
// in the Use Antenna Offsets section.
Configuration.middleAntenna: Double = 3.57
// The device height.
// Distance from the bottom of the device to the center (cm).
// (15.2 cm by default - In most cases, this value should not
// be changed)
// Note: Detailed information on these parameters can be found
// in the Use Antenna Offsets section.
Configuration.deviceHeight: Double = 15.2

inlineContent.text: This completes the change configuration parameters procedure.
All methods and functions specified in this manual are also available in the
